= Momentum and Collisions =

== TL;DR ==

*Momentum*
{{$
  \vec{p} = m\vec{v}
}}$

*Elastic collision where one particle starts at rest*
{{$
  v_1^\prime = \frac{m_1-m_2}{m_1+m_2}v_1
}}$

== Momentum ==

{{$
\vec{p} = m\vec{v}
}}$

{{$
\frac{\Delta\vec{p}}{\Delta t} = \vec{F}
}}$

{{$
\Sigma \vec{p} = [constant]
}}$

{{$
\frac{\Delta \vec{P}}{\Delta t} = \vec{F}_{\mathrm{ext}}
}}$

== Center of Mass ==

{{$
x_{CM} = \frac{\Sigma m_n x_n}{\Sigma m_n}
}}$

*Gravitational potential energy*
{{$
U = Mgy_{CM}
}}$
Where $M$ is the total mass and $y_{CM}$ is the center of mass along the y-axis.

== The Motion of the Center of Mass ==

{{$
\vec{P} = M\vec{v}_{CM}
}}$

{{$
\vec{F}_{\mathrm{ext}} = M\vec{a}_{CM}
}}$

*Kinetic energy of a system*
{{$
K = \Sigma \frac{1}{2}m_n v_n^2
}}$
Simply the sum of of the kinetic energy

== Collisions ==

*Average force*
{{$
\overline{\vec{F}} = \frac{\vec{p}' - \vec{p}}{\Delta t}
}}$
Where $\vec{p}$ is the initial momentum, and $\vec{p}'$ is the final momentum.

*Elastic collision*

A collision in which the kinetic energy before and after is the same is called elastic.

== Elastic Collisions On a Straight Line ==

In an elastic collision of two particles moving along a straight line,
the laws of conservation of momentum and energy
completely determine the final velocities in terms of the initial velocities.

{{$
m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 = m_1v_1' + m_2v_2'
}}$
and
{{$
\frac{1}{2} m_1 v_1^2 + \frac{1}{2} m_2 v_2^2 = \frac{1}{2} m_1 v_1^{\prime 2} + \frac{1}{2} m_2 v_2^{\prime 2}
}}$

If one of the two particles start at rest, we have

{{$
\begin{equation}
  m_1v_1 = m_1v_1^\prime + m_2v_2^\prime
  \label{momentum1}
\end{equation}
}}$
{{$
\begin{equation}
  m_1(v_1-v_1^\prime) = m_2v_2^\prime
  \label{momentum2}
\end{equation}
}}$
and
{{$
\begin{equation}
  \frac{1}{2} m_1 v_1^2 = \frac{1}{2} m_1 v_1^{2\prime} + \frac{1}{2} m_2 v_2^{\prime 2}
  \label{energy1}
\end{equation}
}}$
{{$
\begin{equation}
  m_1(v_1^2-v_1^{\prime 2}) = m_2v_2^{\prime 2}
  \label{energy2}
\end{equation}
}}$
{{$
\begin{equation}
  m_1(v_1-v_1^\prime)(v_1+v_1^\prime) = m_2v_2^{\prime 2}
  \label{energy3}
\end{equation}
}}$
Divide $\eqref{energy3}$ by $\eqref{momentum2}$
{{$
\begin{equation}
  v_1 + v_1^\prime = v_2^\prime
  \label{energymomentum1}
\end{equation}
}}$
Combine $\eqref{energymomentum1}$ and $\eqref{momentum2}$
{{$
\begin{equation}
  m_1(v_1 - v_1^\prime) = m_2(v_1 + v_1^\prime)
  \label{energymomentum2}
\end{equation}
}}$
{{$
\begin{equation}
  v_1^\prime = \frac{m_1-m_2}{m_1+m_2}v_1
  \label{energymomentumsolution}
\end{equation}
}}$


== Inelastic Collisions On a Straight Line ==

*Totally inelastic collision*

If the collision is totally inelastic, so a maximum of kinetic energy is lost,
then the conservation of momentum suffices
to determine the velocities of both particles after the collision.

{{$
v_1' = v_2' = v_{CM} = \frac{m_1v_1}{m_1+m_2}
}}$
